HSS 2020 Authors' Pitch

Welcome to the HSS 2020 Authors’ Book Pitch!

At a time when in-person interaction and exchange is limited, the Authors’ Book Pitch provides a platform to share new and exciting scholarship. We have invited authors of monographs and editors of collective volumes published in the history of science, technology and medicine in 2019 or 2020 to share their work with the HSS and SHOT community in 3-minute videos. Transcripts are also available. Feel free to browse through our videos and learn about the newest releases, directly from the source!

(Note: the videos will be available through the first weekend after our meeting and will be deleted when we close our conference platform.)
 

Traveling with the Atom: A Scientific Guide to Europe and Beyond

Royal Society of Chemistry (2020)

Glen E. Rodgers

In Traveling with the Atom you will visit homesteads, graveyards, laboratories, apartments, abbeys, castles, and even a temple. You will be guided to picturesque villages as well as elegant and romantic cities in Europe that celebrate the lives and minds of great atomic thinkers

Watch Read
 

Creatures of Cain: The Hunt for Human Nature in Cold War America

Princeton University Press (2019)

Erika Lorraine Milam

Drawing on a wealth of archival materials and in-depth interviews, Milam charts the rise and precipitous fall in Cold War America of a theory that attributed early humanity's evolutionary success to their (purported) unique capacity for murder.

Watch Read
 

The Power of the Periphery: How Norway Became an Environmental Pioneer for the World

Cambridge University Press (2020)

Peder J. Anker

This book is exploring the role of Norwegian scholar-activists of the late twentieth century portrayed Norway as a place of environmental stability in a world filled with tension. Norway's power, they argued, lay in the pristine, ideal natural environment of the periphery. Open Access - FREE

Watch Read
 

How Knowledge Moves. Writing the Transnational History of Science and Technology

University of Chicago Press (2019)

John M. Krige

This book takes the content of knowledge itself as the object of transnational analysis, and uses about a dozen case studies to show how it is denied, selectively appropriated, and refashioned as it crosses borders in a world of interstate rivalry and multilateral collaboration.

Watch Read
 

A Rainbow Palate: How Chemical Dyes Changed the West's Relationship with Food

University of Chicago Press (2020)

Carolyn A. Cobbold

Rainbow Palate – how chemical dyes changed our food - a cautionary tale about the unintended consequences of cutting edge science and how chemists lost control of their science

Watch Read
 

Republic of Numbers: Unexpected Stories of Mathematical Americans Through History

Johns Hopkins University Press (2019)

David Lindsay Roberts

This book recounts the life stories of a diverse set of Americans, illustrating the evolution of mathematical activity in this country over more than 200 years. It should appeal to anyone interested in mathematics or American history or both. Use the code HTWN to save 20%

Watch Read
 

Einstein in Bohemia

Princeton University Press (2020)

Michael D. Gordin

Einstein in Bohemia starts with the encounter of Albert Einstein and the city of Prague — where he lived and taught physics from April 1911 to August 1912 — and then follows his interactions amid the cultural ferment of late Habsburg Prague.

Watch Read
 

Hearing Happiness: Deafness Cures in History

University of Chicago Press (2020)

Jaipreet Virdi

Through lyrical history and personal memoir, Hearing Happiness raises pivotal questions about deafness in American society and the endless quest for a cure—a harmful legacy that is still present in contemporary biomedicine. HSS discount code for 30% off: EX56719

Watch Read
 

Know Your Remedies: Pharmacy and Culture in Early Modern China

Princeton University Press (2020)

He Bian

A cultural history of the concept of pharmacy, both the material nature of drugs and the trade in medicine, in early modern China. He Bian (@bowarrowstreet)'s new book provides a panoramic inquiry into China’s early modern cultural transformation through the lens of pharmacy.

Watch Read
 

Heredity under the Microscope: Chromosomes and the Study of the Human Genome

University of Chicago Press (2020)

Soraya de Chadarevian

For much of the second half of the twentieth century pictures of orderly paired chromosomes were the most recognizable images of genetics. Heredity under the Microscope follows their use in and out of the laboratory and their role in discussions on heredity in humans. For 30% exhibit discount go to www.press.uchicago.edu/directmail and use keycode EX56720

Watch Read
 

Jane Addams's Evolutionary Theorizing: Constructing Democracy and Social Ethics

University of Chicago Press (2019)

Marilyn Fischer

Can social evolutionary theorizing be ethical? Was Jane Addams really a scientist? Yes! Read how in one jargon-free book, Jane Addams's Evolutionary Theorizing: Constructing Democracy and Social Ethics, by Marilyn Fischer. Discount Code: UCPNEW

Watch Read
 

David Bohm - A Life Dedicated to Understanding the Quantum World

Springer (2019)

Olival Freire Junior

Some people considered Bohm’s work on the foundations of quantum mechanics worthless while others saw Bohm’s work on quantum mechanics and philosophy as a panacea. Both were wrong. This biography shows his attempts to understand the quantum, a quest he left unfinished.

Watch Read
 

The Myth of the Perfect Pregnancy: A History of Miscarriage in America

Oxford University Press (2020)

Lara Freidenfelds

A history of how Americans came to have unrealistic expectations that every pregnancy could be made perfect, and how even early pregnancy losses came to be devastating for many women. Includes STS analyses of ultrasound, pregnancy tests, embryo development timelines, and more. Order online at www.oup.com/academic with promo code AAFLYG6 to save 30%

Watch Read
 

Evolution before Darwin: Theories of the Transmutation of Species in Edinburgh, 1804–1834

Edinburgh University Press (2019)

Bill Jenkins

This book is the first major study of what was probably the most important centre or pre-Darwinian evolutionary thought in the British Isles. It sheds new light on the genesis and development of one of the most important scientific theories in the history of western thought.

Watch Read
 

Testing Hearing. The Making of Modern Aurality

Oxford University Press (2020)

Viktoria Tkaczyk, Mara Mills, and Alexandra Hui (eds.)

"Testing Hearing: The Making of Modern Aurality" considers both the testing of hearing and testing with hearing to explore the co-creation of modern epistemic and auditory cultures. Viktoria Tkaczyk, Mara Mills, and Alexandra Hui (eds.), Testing Hearing. The Making of Modern Aurality (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2020), online: https://oxford.universitypressscholarship.com/view/10.1093/oso/9780197511121.001.0001/oso-9780197511121

Watch Read
 

Higher and Colder: A History of Extreme Physiology and Exploration

University of Chicago Press (2019)

Vanessa Heggie

Higher and Colder tells the history of a neglected modern science (physiology) in a neglected space (the field), and in so doing offers new insight into how scientific authority is established in a complex, global world via an often dangerous, gendered and racialised practice

Watch Read
 

Leonardo da Vinci Cartographer and Inventor of the Google Map

DaVinci Press (2019)

Ann Pizzorusso

Leonardo da Vinci invented the Google Map. Publisher will offer the ebook free on October 10, 2020. To access the offer go to the Amazon.com site.

Watch Read
 

The Green Revolution in the Global South: Science, Politics, and Unintended Consequences

University of Alabama Press (2020)

Ray Douglas Hurt

This is a survey of the Green Revolution from the early 1940s to the present. In it, I discuss the development, benefits, and consequences of the Green Revolution in Mexico, India and Pakistan, China, Southeast Asia, and Sub-Sahara Africa.

Watch Read
 

Working With Paper: Gendered Practices in the History of Knowledge

University of Pittsburgh Press (2019)

Carla Bittel, Elaine Leong, Christine von Oertzen (eds.)

In this book, we examine the history and materiality of paperstuff to unlock a new history of knowledge. We uncover the intricate negotiations of gender and power underlying both learned and quotidian practices, showing how paper matters beyond the page. Use code HSS20 to get a discount of 30% for online purchase via the PUP website.

Watch Read
 

Science, Religion, and the Protestant Tradition: Retracing the Origins of Conflict

University of Pittsburgh Press (2019)

James C. Ungureanu

My book revisits the origins, development, and popularization of the "conflict thesis," the idea that science and religion are in fundamental conflict. But in my book I argue that the “conflict thesis” was one of the many unintended consequences of the Protestant Reformation.

Watch Read
 

Boxes: A Field Guide

Mattering Press, Manchester UK (2020)

Susanne Bauer, Martina Schlünder, and Maria Rentetzi (eds.)

A book full of boxes. A box in itself. An unboxing. Gathered in the format of a field guide, this collation of essays offers an introduction to ways of ordering the world, unpacking their boxed-up, largely invisible politics and epistemics. Available as paperback and fully open access (PDF, ePub, Kindle) at: https://www.matteringpress.org/books/boxes

Watch Read
 

The Science of Useful Nature in Central America: Landscapes, Networks and Practical Enlightenment, 1784–1838

Cambridge University Press (2020)

Sophie Brockmann

Scientific knowledge drawn from local networks and global Enlightenment thought was key to shaping the modern nations of Central America. SUNCA2020 20% discount

Watch Read
 

Astronomy of the Inca Empire: Use and Significance of the Sun and the Night Sky

Springer Nature (2020)

Steven R. Gullberg

Astronomy in the Inca Empire was a robust and fundamental practice. Through modern archaeoastronomy and imagery this book helps to recover and interpret fascinating elements of Inca civilization. Over 300 images - with more than 260 in color - are included throughout the book.

Watch Read
 

Poisonous Skies: Acid Rain and the Globalization of Pollution

University of Chicago Press (2019)

Rachel Emma Rothschild

Grounded in archival research spanning eight countries and five languages, as well as interviews with leading scientists from both government and industry, Poisonous Skies is the first book to examine the history of acid rain in an international context.

Watch Read
 

Thrifty Science: Making the Most of Materials in Early Modern Experiment

University of Chicago Press (2019)

Simon Werrett

Thrifty Science explores the distinctive culture of domestic experiment in the early modern period and demonstrates how the values of the household helped to shape an array of experimental inquiries.

Watch Read
 

Catastrophic Thinking: Extinction and the Value of Diversity from Darwin to the Anthropocene

University of Chicago Press (2020)

David Sepkoski

Why do we care about biological and cultural diversity, and why do we fear its loss? Catastrophic Thinking argues that we can answer these questions only by understanding the way extinction has been understood as a cultural and scientific concept over the past 200 years. To order books from this meeting online, go to www.press.uchicago.edu/directmail and use keycode EX56720 to apply the 30% exhibit discount. This will allow you to purchase the book for the discounted price of $24.50.

Watch Read
 

Leeuwenhoek's Legatees and Beijerinck's Beneficiaries: A History of Medical Virology in The Netherlands

Amsterdam University Press (2020)

Neeraja Sankaran

Traveling from laboratory to laboratory, Leeuwenhoek’s Legatees and Beijerinck’s Beneficiaries follows the history of medical virology in the Netherlands and former Dutch colonies. As such, it shows the diverse and international character of medical research in the 20th century. Free (Open access) PDF version of book available through this link: https://library.oapen.org/handle/20.500.12657/22972.

Watch Read
 

America by the Numbers. Quantification, Democracy, and the Birth of National Statistics

MIT Press (2020)

Emmanuel Didier

A book about the intertwining of National statistics and politicizes in the US in the XXth c. How random sampling is inherently tied to the New Deal. How statisticians had to become detectives and anthropologists, searching for elements that would help them portray America.

Watch
 

From Cells to Organisms, Re-Envisioning Cell Theory

University of Toronto Press (2020)

Sherrie Lynne lyons

Thomas Huxley's critique of cell theory provides the scaffolding for an exploration of how cell theory shaped research and that results are interpreted not only through the lens of a microscope, but through the lens of particular ideas and prior philosophical convictions. To request exam or desk copies of From Cells to Organisms or any other UTP title, please email requests@utorontopress.com and be sure to include the course name and number, start date, and estimated enrollment.

Watch Read
 

A Pioneer of Connection: Recovering the Life and Work of Oliver Lodge

Pittsburgh University Press (2020)

Edited By James Mussell and Graeme Gooday

How did Oliver Lodge (1851-1940) become one of the most widely read scientists in his lifetime? Empathic connections with his audiences on shared human concerns informed his communication of physics, technology, well-being and the after-life. Therein lay his public authority.

Watch Read
 

The Life and Science of Harold C. Urey

University of Chicago Press (2020)

Matthew Shindell

Harold C. Urey (1893–1981) rose to fame alongside the prestige of 20th C American science. This biography examines the life and career of this enigmatic figure as a way of understanding changes in the social and intellectual landscape of American science, politics, and religion.

Watch Read
 

Sailing School: Navigating Science and Skill, 1550-1800

Johns Hopkins University Press (2019)

Margaret E. Schotte

This comparative study of how early modern sailors learned the science of navigation takes us into classrooms, bookstores, and examination halls, as well as onto ships’ decks. Navigators' manuscripts show how they relied on both theory *and* practice to succeed at sea. Use code HTWN for 30% off.

Watch Read
 

FIRST WOMAN: Joanne Simpson and the Tropical Atmosphere

Oxford University Press (2020)

James Rodger Fleming

My new book, First Woman: Joanne Simpson and the Tropical Atmosphere is about Joanne’s personal and professional life, her career prospects as a woman in science, and her relationship to the tropical atmosphere. My new book, First Woman: Joanne Simpson and the Tropical Atmosphere is about Joanne’s personal and professional life, her career prospects as a woman in science, and her relationship to the tropical atmosphere. Use promo code ASPROMP8 for a 30% discount

Watch Read
 

The Lived Nile: Environment, Disease, and Material Colonial Economy in Egypt

Stanford University Press (2019)

Jennifer L. Derr

From the microscopic to the regional, the local to the imperial, The Lived Nile traces the history and centrality of the environment in Egypt to questions of politics, knowledge, and the lived experience of the human body itself.

Watch Read
 

Performing Math: A History of Communication and Anxiety in the American Mathematics Classroom

Rutgers University Press (2020)

Andrew Fiss

"Performing Math: A History of Communication and Anxiety in the American Mathematics Classroom" by Andrew Fiss, new from Rutgers University Press! Civil-War-Era student performances - plus classroom expectations for students' reading, writing, speaking about math - equals fun!

Watch Read
